title: Noctes Ambrosianæ.
author: Wilson, John
snippet: But hush your havers, Mr. De Quinshy ; and tell me, Mr. North, what for ye didna come out to Innerleithen and fish for the silver medal of the St. Ronan's Border Club ! I'm thinkin ye was feared.

title: The works of Professor Wilson of the University of Edinburgh,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: By mincing our steps, indeed, one might contrive to stop at Innerleithen ; but suppose a gadfly were to sting one's hip at the Pirn — ono unintentional stride would deposit Christopher at Drummelzier, and another over the Cruik, and far away down Annan Water! Therefore, there is notliing like wings.

title: The works of Professor Wilson of the University of Edinburgh,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: murmur, when torrent retreats before tide, and the birds of ocean come floating into the inland woods ! Oh ! that, " like Horeb's rock beneath the Prophet's hand," yonder steep would let escape into light the living waters ! But this wish is a mere wliim of the moment ; and therefore it is our delight to escape for a week to the brooks of Peebles, or Innerleithen, or Clovenford, or Kelso.

title: Essays critical and imaginative,
author: Wilson, John
snippet: By mincing our steps, indeed, one might contrive to stop at Innerleithen ; but suppose a gadfly were to sting one's hip at the Pirn — one unintentional stride would deposit Christopher at Drummelzier, and another over the Cruik, and far away down Annan Water ! Therefore, there is nothing like wings.

title: Essays critical and imaginative,

Oh ! that, " like Horeb's rock beneath the Prophet's hand," yonder steep would let escape into light the living waters ! But this wish is a mere whim of the moment ; and therefore it is our delight to escape for a week to the brooks of Peebles, or Innerleithen, or Clovenford, or Kelso.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: At a short distance from Innerleithen, is Pirn ; and three miles further on, entering Selkirkshire, is Holylee (Ballantyne, Esq.) A mile beyond, on the opposite side of the river, are the ruins of Elibank Tower, from which Lord Elibauk takes his title.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: Till little more than forty years ago, Innerleithen was one of the smallest and most primitive hamlets in this pastoral district  ; and it would probably have continued so, but for the beautiful description given of it by Sir Walter Scott, in his novel of St. Ronan's Well.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: From Peebles a pleasant excursion may be made to Innerleithen,  six miles distant.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: In summer months a coach runs in connection ^^^th the riiilway from Peebles to Innerleithen.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: To the angling district of Peebles and Innerleithen.

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: " The most remarkable  of these are — the sulphureous waters of Stratlqieffer, near Dingwall, Ross-shire ; Muirtown, in the same neighbourhood ; Moffat, in Dumfriesshire ; and St. BernarcVs, at Stockbridge, a suburb of Edinburgh ; the chalybeates of Hartfell, near Moffat ; Vicars Bridge, near Dollar, Stirlingshire ; and Bonnington,  near Edinburgh ; the saline waters of Dunhlane, near Stirling ; Airthrie, also near Stirling ; Pitcaithly, near Perth ; and Innerleithen, near Peebles.

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: We set out early on the 18th, and ascended the Tweed, passing in succession Yair, Ashestiel, Innerleithen, Traquair,  and many more scenes dear to his early life, and celebrated in his writings.
